answers.answer: perform anti TGab and anti TPOab tests !
I had TPOab done, but not TGab.<10        0 - 34

Here's a link you might find interesting:http://www.custommedicine.com.au/blog/2007/04/17/reverse-t3-dominance/Also, google "T3 RT3 ratio" and you'll have plenty of reading...First of all, your RT3 is not "normal"; your doctor shouldn't be ignoring it.  The article also suggests that it's the ratio of T3 to RT3 that's important.  It should be between 1.06 and 2.2 "preferably at the upper end of this range".  T3/RT3 * 100 is the formula.  So, yours is 2.7/362 * 100 = 0.75...very low.You may need to find a good thyroid expert.

Thank you for doing my ratio.  I just don't get the concept right now.  I have so much brain fog and I can't concentrate.I checked out the web site and I will do more reserch.I know I need to find a new doctor. I thought I finally found the right one because he did agree to order more tests than any other doctor I've been to in years.  Especially the Adrenal saliva test and RT3.Thanks again, Jena

Goolara, I think you must work in statistics!Jena, you should get the TGab test, too. You can be positive in one and not the other. Also, get a thyroid ultrasound. Your freeT3/T4 are on the low end of normal. You would probably do well with some thyroid hormone. What would it have hurt the doctor to try you on a low dose and go from there? Geez!Find a doc who can treat your frees and not your TSH, which is a pituitary hormone. At least this one did the reverse T3. That's a start. Now you need to find a doc who actually knows how to recognize and treat low numbers.Jena, here's the site where I found my endo. It's not fool proof. Call ahead and ask how many thyroid vs diabetes patients this doc treats. Too many endos specialize in diabetes, not thryoid!http://www.thyroid-info.com/topdrs/:) Tamra

Is the TGab Antithyroglobulin Ab?  If so I had it done.<20          0 - 40And I also had an thyroid ultrasound.Revealed a relatively homogeneous thyroid gland.  The right  lobe measures 4.5 x 1.5 x 1.5 cm and the left 4.3 x 1.2 x0.8 cm.There is hypoechoic solid nodule in the mid pole of the right lobe measuring 0.7 mm with a calcified wall.  The hypoechoic non calcified solid nodule is seen in the lower pole of the right lobe.Small hypoechoic nodule is seen in the upper left lobe anteriorly.  The isthmus is slightly enlarged measuring 4.0 mm.ImpressionAlthough the appearance of the thyroid is predominantly homogeneous nodules are seen in the thyroid gland.  There are two on the right side and the larger one has acalcified wall in the upper pole of the left lobe.I looked on http://www.thyroid-info.com/topdrs/ and found two doctors that I will call today.Thank you so much for taking time out during this busy holiday seaon to reply.Jena

To put it in less mathematical terms:  you should have roughly equal amounts of FT3 and RT3, at the lower end, to roughly twice the amount of FT3 to RT3, at the upper end.  You have less FT3 than RT3, and this can cause hypo symptoms even though your FT3 and FT4 are both within range.  It's technically not hypothyroidism, but a failure to metabolize FT4 into FT3 properly.I think a new doctor is definitely in order.  Too many don't understand basic thyroid problems, let alone anything a bit more complicated or unusual.  Interview your prospective doctors (probably through a nurse) over the phone before making an appointment and ask them flat out if they have expertise in treating RT3 dominance.  You could save yourself a lot of time and money.

question: I finally got my RT3 results.  I'm very confused. My doctor said that all of my lab results are normal.  I know from being on this forum that my FT3 should be in the higher range and it's not.  I have a high RT3, but is that a problem?  I feel that my adrenal saliva test results are low, but please tell me if they are considered low.  Should I be taking meds?  I have symptoms if horrible hairloss, can't sleep, dizzy, tired, brain fog, depression, low temperature, digestive problems, sinus problems, and on and on.My results areT4, Free Direct                        1.02                          0.61 - 1.76TSH                                          0.942                     0.450 - 4.500Free T3                                      2.7                          2.3 - 4.2Reverse T3	         	362 H pg/ml              90 - 350Dihydrotestosterone                    3.2                             4 - 22Saliva Adrenal Results7:00            0.310                0.025 - 0.60012:00          0.010             < 0.010 - 0.3304:00            0.019                0.010 - 0.20011:00       < 0.010             < 0.010 - 0.090The doctor is not going to give me meds.  He said I should go gluten free, no soy or dairy.  Is this going to help any of my problems other than digestive?Should I look for another doctor?  My hairloss has been going on for almost 2 years and that is how long I have been trying to find out what is wrong with me and going to different doctors.Please help, Jena
title: HELP with Test Results
